positive.review:
Tired of AAA games, tired of Souls clones that can't even get the feeling and pacing right. I'm looking for a simpler experience that doesn't sacrifice depth, glad to find it here.

Edit: Now that I'm finished with the game and got all the achievements, I can confidently say that this is a fantastic game, it's a fantastic game if you see it for what it is and not for what you want it to be. I saw someone complaining about the game looking like a bad tech demo with how undetailed the environment is, which if you're judging this game based on how AAA looks you're missing the point. This is a gameplay focused game that offers a tight gameplay experience, not an interactive movie. If you want to look at the most cutting edge and detailed graphics why go here in the first place.

If you're thinking about buying this game to play with your friends, I want you to keep in mind the kind of people you're playing with. The kind of people you're playing with will greatly, like I mean greatly change your first experience with the game. I first played with my friends that already had over 100 hours in the game, and I did not have fun. I couldn't keep up simply because of the knowledge gap, they have a better understanding of the map layout and everything while I don't. So when I die, I was never able to catch up. They got overpowered and have a ton of fun while I'm struggling to survive. Which ended up making me dismissed the game by "This game is not for me I guess." (Or "this shit fucking sucks" depending on what kind of person you're).

But I decided to go back solo and really give the game a chance. I'm just gonna play and have fun, which is exactly what I did. I didn't care about the timer, I didn't care about playing fast, I didn't care if I die and I'm just gonna vibe. This time, I had fun, I really had fun and I got the satisfaction of "The Click" with the game. The game really just lets you play however you want, it asks you to be efficient, but you will naturally get more efficient the more time you play, so you don't have to be stressed out on playing efficiently. The pacing in this game is great, amazing even.

I love this game, I didn't expect it would make it to my top 8 favorite games but I'm glad it did, I had an amazing time playing it.

Also I wish that Eclipse 8 is an achievement, something called "King of Petrichor V, Beat the game on Eclipse 8 with every Survivor." I only did one Eclipse 8 win, simply because I don't think that it's worth it unless this is your number one favorite and you love it dearly. But having to play each Survivor 7 times before unlocking the difficulty just feels tedious, I would rather they just make it so you only need to get one Eclipse 8 win to unlock it for any other characters.

But yea, give this game a try I promise you it's worth it, especially now that it's on discount.

This is a cool roguelite with a lot of variety, but you have to give it a decent try before you see any fun in it as your progression is directly tied with your own skill and experience of the game. You're thrown into a level with tooltips as your tutorial, all items are "???" until you buy them (and you should so you know what they do in your future runs), and overall it's a big game of trial and error.

For the first hour or so of playing RoR2, I was confused why this game had overwhelmingly positive reviews because the gameplay was 'alright', you run around shooting enemies to level up and get money to open crates to get items, ultimately to prepare for the teleporter event which leads you into a boss battle then the next stage where you repeat all of that again. Maybe singleplayer wasn't as good as the multiplayer? But once I got a decent run going I began to see why it is pretty fun, and in that same run I managed to escape and win which was incredibly satisfying. 

The amount of items you can collect strikes a good balance between too little and too much, as you're able to find new items consistently while also getting already found items to stack your character with. Once you get yourself a bunch of items, you start feeling like an unstoppable in-game boss. I once had 8 of one item (and their stats stack) and every kill rewarded me with 120 temporary health, but then I accidentally scrapped all of them because I didn't know the scrap machine would do that... and that is the only part of the game that frustrates me which is you don't know anything until you do it, and that may end your 2hr run.

Let me start by saying Risk of Rain 2 is an excellent game—fast-paced action, enough item stacking to legally qualify as hoarding, and a soundtrack that makes you feel like you’re leaping through space in slow motion.

But here’s the problem: there is absolutely zero rain.
None. Not a drizzle. Not even a polite mist. I checked. I waited. I even equipped items that sounded wet.

What is there?

- Fantastic soundtrack

- Gambling addiction

- Fast-paced roguelite mechanics

- More content than most triple A titles for a fraction of the price


What is not there?

- Rain

- Any rain at all

- Not even the risk of rain
(At this point, the only thing at risk is my blood pressure.)

But despite the outrageous lack of meteorological implementation, the game is still incredibly fun.
(Yes I know there are a couple stages with what one could [i] barely [/i] argue is rain).

AMAZING GAME, so much fun unlocking new characters and abilities, being able to loop over and over to become overpowered and destroy everything and anything. The design is slick and is pleasing to the eye. The different maps look beautiful with so many places to explore! Undoubtedly would recommend.

Incredible atmosphere:
The pixel art is minimal, but the game feels strangely haunting. The soundtrack, ambient sounds, and level design come together to create this lonely, lost-in-space vibe that sticks with you.

Addictive progression loop:
Finding items and slowly turning your character into an absolute monster is incredibly satisfying. No two runs feel the same; every time you’re wondering, “What kind of build am I going to end up with this time?”

Challenging but fair:
It’s not an easy game, but it rarely feels cheap. Most of the time when you die, you know exactly what you did wrong. That makes it very rewarding to improve and push a bit further with each run.

Shines in co-op:
Playing with friends takes the chaos to another level. The screen fills with enemies, items drop everywhere, and you’re constantly discussing who should pick what. It’s hectic in the best way.

Compact, yet memorable:
It’s not a huge AAA title, but it absolutely has that “cult classic” energy. For the price and the amount of hours you can sink into it, it’s an amazing value.

Risk of Rain is a gripping, replayable, and atmospheric roguelike that pulls you into its loop of die–learn–get stronger–repeat in the most satisfying way. If you enjoy games that reward skill, adaptation, and a bit of chaos, it’s absolutely worth playing.

This is the most enjoyable and endlessly repeatable 3D-shooter roguelike for co-op. Each playthrough is different due to the randomized treasure chest perks, sometimes this results in hilarious builds. 
The difficulty escalates the longer you play, so the game gets intense and insane towards the 40-60 minute mark. 

I appreciate the blend of Pixel art and watercolor, this paints a very clean and appealing aesthetic.

Please be aware this game has some flaws, soloing gets very repetitive very fast and I had consistently encountered the same glitch at the final level where you re prevented from fighting the last boss. 
(this problem is easy to solve on steamdeck, just go to settings and disable cross-platform option, meaning you can only play with friends who have this game on Steam).

There are other bugs, but it does not detract from the experience too much if you can work around it.  This game is often on sale, so I highly recommend it for co-op enjoyment!

Risk of Rain 2 // One of the Best Roguelikes There is . . .

// Risk of Rain 2 has one of the most addictive gameplay loops there are in roguelikes. Even though the principal is pretty much the same every time, get items, go to teleporter, and then beat boss, there is so much you can do to make your run incredibly unique! Especially with DLCs like Survivors of the Void and Alloyed Collective, there is so much more to add to your experience with the new maps and new items that each DLC offers. There is a unique variety in the characters you play in ROR2 so each item and map has a whole different feel based on the character you select (this is a good thing). Also, the music in this game is phenomenal, even across all three DLCs too! It's both incredibly upbeat and also very somber at times which makes you appreciate the beautiful world of Petrichor V a whole lot more. Apart from the music, the game is very stylistic too, taking inspiration from the original 2D Risk of Rain and reimagining it for a 3D world! Along with games like the Binding of Isaac: Rebirth, Risk of Rain 2 stands tall!

[h1] My favourite game and why [/h1]
Genuinely the best rougelike I've ever played and in my opinion the best rougelike fullstop, learning every corner of stacking, proccing, synergising items is perfect since I can recognise instantly what my build can turn into depending on what I find in a run. And then majority of the time it never feels like I'm scrambling to get a good build going unless I literally get better at the game since even an overpowered build doesn't mean being invulnerable.
Music is top notch, making me feel like I'm on top the world while my screen is filled with unimaginable colours and particles, every soundtrack to each and every major boss making so much sense and making me feel desperate the finish the fight in anyway to avoid dying.
Can't even begin to describe how the lore, hidden yet so obvious, makes me feel as it tells such a tragic story over multiple games and how the world came to be in the vision of the developers, making me even tear up in how tragic yet perfect it really is to make everything make sense in terms of why these items are here, why they do what they do, the environments and their storytelling, all to culminate in a final boss that really shows how to do a final boss correctly.
And that's all in just the base game alone, the DLC's make the expierence even more enjoyable with expanding even more on items, story, run experience and variation making it so that I never have the same run twice ever.
In the end Risk of Rain 2 is one of my favourite games of all time and I [b] [u] WILL [/u] [/b] be spending hundrends upon hundreds of hours towards the goal of 100% completion one day.

Risk of Rain is a love letter to the roguelike genre, providing hours of randomized enjoyment or hours of choosing all of your items to make your survivor into a freak of nature with ten red sunglasses. There are so many ways to play and enjoy this game, from suffering on eclipse mode to unwinding on drizzle mode, or playing a poison doggo, or alternatively a normal soldier, or you know, a god (DLC Character). Not to mention the art, OST, and lore (If you know where to look) that add so much to game. Risk of Rain 2 is a truly unique experience that I believe everyone that likes the roguelike genre should try, and then subsequently lose their entire afternoon. I got engulfed in the world of Risk of Rain and I don't think I can stop anymore, and I hope for the sake of the people that made this game so close to my heart that you please buy it, the only regret you'll have is all of the time you've wasted lost on Petrichor V

Risk of Rain isn’t just a game to me — it’s an experience I keep coming back to because nothing else quite captures the magic it has. There’s something almost godly about its concept… that perfect blend of chaos, curiosity, progression, and mystery that no other game seems to deliver in the same way. I constantly crave this feeling in other titles, but Risk of Rain stands alone. It’s special.

Every run feels like a personal journey. Even when I think I’ve mastered something, the game surprises me with a new mechanic, a new synergy, or a new way to approach challenges. It’s wild how a single run can teach me something completely new — sometimes small, sometimes mind-blowing — but always rewarding.

There’s a sense of growth that doesn’t rely only on the character leveling up, but me leveling up. I learn, adapt, experiment, fail, laugh, and hype myself up all over again. That loop — that constant feeling of discovery — is what makes Risk of Rain feel so incredibly good.

It’s one of those rare games that isn’t just fun; it becomes a comfort space. A beautiful storm of action, music, atmosphere, and progression that just hits a part of my gamer-heart no other game reaches. And honestly… I adore it for that.

Risk of Rain isn’t just a roguelike. It’s a vibe. A feeling. A little universe I’m always excited to jump back into. And I love it more with every run.

This might be the worst roguelight on the market today, and I genuinely regret wasting the time on it I have. Why?

The game is sadistic, plain and simple. It oozes out of every pore of the gameplay, EVEN including the hints. The very first lesson you get: "Take too long, and the enemies will get stronger!" "Don't waste time!" These are lies. You cannot blitz through the game, because RNG will punish you. Have no items? Tanky enemies will spawn and the time it takes you to kill them without damage buffs is so long you would have spent the same time getting BUFFS AND KILLING THEM that you did on just killing them.

The most basic enemy, the wisp, can spawn behind you, out of your line of sight, MID-ATTACK ANIMATION and hit you before their audio warning for spawning EVEN FINISHES. These attacks are borderline impossible to dodge without the use of a block or bunny-hop spam. Because some moron gave hitscan to a basic mob.

Bosses "scale" over time, but the game intentionally wastes as much of yours as possible. The portals take FOREVER to charge up, so rushing the boss down is meaningless. You get no reward for playing well. Only more of your time wasted.

Speaking of RNG: There are two horrific systems in this game that make my eyes roll into the back of my head: Portals and Boss Spawns.

The portals can be added to the teleporter by achieving certain small "goals," but most of them are horrible pains in the butt that waste your time to get! In a game about getting loot as fast as possible to scale up with the enemies, it sure would be so FUNNY and WACKY if the game devs hid randomly spawning newt statues in places unreachable for over half the roster! That would be SO WACKY~ So FUNNY~ It would also be funny if those characters would benefit the MOST from getting it!? But also, haha, what if the newt statue doesn't spawn at ALL and you wastes MINUTES looking for it in SUPER HIDDEN spots because you need one of those items!? HAHAHAHAHAHA~

There are so painfully few teleporter boss enemies that the Devs could be mistaken for a recycling plant. Do you like TITAN or BEETLE MOM? Too bad! That's ALL you will see 99% of the time. Don't worry, though! You can fight multiples of them AT ONCE so you can visually see the re-used content before your very eyes~! Three expansions in and we can't be bothered to add more variety to the BASE gameplay? No. You need more RNG in your items, of course!! Have 20 more items in the pool!

Bosses start to spawn as basic enemies as the time scales up. Sure would suck if the bosses that do spawn are boring slop that spam laser attacks or mobs. With the ability to spawn as elites. With HP so high they actually become tankier than their non-elite, normal boss counterparts. Haha. And like, imagine if they could spawn as HEALING elites!? That's so funny! Haha! And like, imagine if bosses weren't coded to be unhealable by these elites!? TEEHEE!? Image if the wave of elites that spawn in around the boss were all copies of the boss that are ALL HEALING ELITES!? That would be SO WACKY~?!

Every basic game design rule was ignored for this game, and it makes me so sad. There is so much potential in this game to be fun, but I am convinced the game devs were too busy thinking of stupid ways to kill the player. I so painfully want to like the game. It has so much charm and love clearly put into it... but the flaws are so upsetting that it makes me want to eat drywall.


For those looking for a fun read on why I'm writing this? I was 35 minutes deep into a Monsoon run. Half-decent build. Definitely no god run, but good enough to finish with. I do the portal before the 4th world and 7 bosses spawn. Why? I don't know. Mountain wasn't active. Immediately, the game spawns 2 entire waves of elite enemies, over half of them healing elites. The bosses are functionally immortal. I spent 20 minutes kiting and slowly killing the healers, beat the bosses, and went into the blue portal. I clearly needed more items, perhaps even Heretic if it was that rough. Despite LOOKING AT THE BLUE PORTAL, with the text prompt for BLUE PORTAL, it sends me into the gold one behind me. I spawn in and there are already 15 enemies on the ground. 12 of them are Halcyonites, with 3 being healing elite Halcyonites. The other 3 are stone titans. 

Genuinely. What the absolute hell am I supposed to do against 15 bosses that all spam lasers, 3 of which are literally undodgeable, and heal each other? Sure, the healing Halcyonites could be slowly chipped down if I had the mental stamina left, but I JUST left a 20 minute grindfest. I tried for 5 minutes, realized I had about 3 seconds out of every 60 to attack safely, just gave up, and let my character die.

I don't care if it was "possible" to do. I care that it wasn't fun in ANY way. If I so much as touch this game again, I will NEVER be playing without cheat engine. I shouldn't have to cheat to make the game fun, but I have just as little respect for a game willing to waste an hour of my life as it does for me.

Tl;Dr - Go play Crab Champions. It's an infinitely better game that does everything this game does, but without the sheer bullshit that is the poorly thought out "elite" system they lazily and poorly implemented in RoR2. A bunch of bosses is one thing: A boss spawning in as an elite that heals %max HP of all nearby allies? No.
Maybe stop making DLCs for the game for once and make actual content for players to engage more together?, this feels hollow.

Risk of Rain 2 doesn’t feel satisfying to play: it becomes repetitive, build development is uninteresting, and progression feels slow. There’s no real sense of danger or urgency.

Some thoughts: the teleport event seems pointless—its only function is to move you to another biome, but there’s no meaningful reset or shift in pacing. Boss fights are significantly harder than regular encounters, yet the reward is the same single item, so defeating a boss doesn’t feel genuinely rewarding.

Opinion: as a roguelike, the game has potential, but it needs substantial rebalancing and a deeper rethink of how builds and progression develop.

In my opinion, Risk of Rain 2 is not only bad at being a roguelite, but bad at being a fun game too. The items are not game-breaking like in other roguelites, you have nearly zero choice in your build, the enemies are incredibly annoying and tedious to fight, and the bosses are not interesting and have way too much health, making it just a slog to fight. The entire game gets boring after 5 minutes, because fighting the same boring basic enemies becomes repetitive, so I am just forced to ignore them; WHICH, FOR SOME REASON, IS ENTIRELY POSSIBLE. The enemies' attacks are not strong for the most part, but for some reason they have stupidly inflated health and are just time-wasters. The ONLY good things about this game are the character/enemy design and art.
